function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Potential for rapid spread of COVID-19 due to digital revolution and IoT advancements.","Impact":"Increased risk of widespread COVID-19 transmission and potential for mutation.","Mitigation":"Public health awareness, vaccination campaigns, and strict monitoring and regulation of digital and IoT technologies.","Technologies":"Advanced data analytics for early detection, IoT sensors for monitoring, and digital contact tracing apps.","People":"General public, especially those in high-density urban areas and healthcare workers.","Owner":"Government health agencies, digital technology companies, and public health organizations."},{"Description":"Lack of cyber-security and privacy in tracking apps and wastewater surveillance.","Impact":"Potential for data breaches, privacy violations, and misuse of personal information.","Mitigation":"Stringent data protection laws, regular security audits, and public education on privacy and data security.","Technologies":"Encryption and secure data transmission protocols for tracking apps, blockchain for data integrity, and advanced cybersecurity measures for wastewater surveillance.","People":"Users of tracking apps, individuals connected to wastewater surveillance systems, and data protection authorities.","Owner":"Tech companies, government regulatory bodies, and privacy advocacy groups."},{"Description":"Inadequate adoption of bio-sensors and smart sanitation technology in infrastructure and sanitation products.","Impact":"Limited ability to detect and monitor emerging contaminants with global health potential.","Mitigation":"Promotion of bio-sensor adoption, research and development of advanced detection technologies, and integration of smart sanitation solutions into public health infrastructure.","Technologies":"Bio-sensor technology for contaminant detection, IoT integration for real-time monitoring, and advanced chemical analysis for water quality assessment.","People":"WASH practitioners, public health stakeholders, and communities reliant on sanitation infrastructure.","Owner":"Public health agencies, sanitation technology developers, and government bodies responsible for infrastructure development."}]}
